journal-title-group.journal-title: Quarterly Journal of Business and Economics

publisher.publisher-name: College of Business Administration of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln

abstract.p: Various simulated returns are used to examine the reliability and robustness of several statistical tests when used to detect shifts in the beta parameter of common stock. The results from simulated daily returns indicate that the widely used recursive residuals approach performs poorly and is not robust. Variable parameter and dummy variable regression and the Chow and Farley-Hinich tests show an ability to detect parameter shifts with acceptable levels of Type I error. The level of Type II error, however, is disappointingly high which indicates that these techniques are inadequate for application to individual cases involving daily data. Tests of the ability of the log likelihood ratio to locate the point of change indicate that the technique is highly inaccurate and inadequate for application to individual cases. The results suggest that previous research using daily returns may have understated the instability of the market parameters.
